action.action-desc: Mr. Burchett (for himself, Mr. Tiffany, Mr. Guest, and Mr. Fitzpatrick) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary, and in addition to the Committee on Energy and Commerce, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned

form.official-title: To amend the Controlled Substances Act to provide for life imprisonment for certain offenses involving Fentanyl, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Fentanyl Trafficker Elimination Act.

section.header: Life imprisonment for certain offenses involving Fentanyl

subsection.text: Section 401(b)(1) of the Controlled Substances Act (21 U.S.C. 841(b)(1)) is amended—

paragraph.text: in subparagraph (A), by repealing clause (vi); and
by adding at the end the following:

subparagraph.text: In the case of a violation of subsection (a) of this section involving 400 grams or more of a mixture or substance containing a detectable amount of N-phenyl-N-[1–(2-phenylethyl)–4-piperidinyl] propanamide or 100 grams or more of a mixture or substance containing a detectable amount of any analogue of N-phenyl-N-[1–(2-phenylethyl)–4-piperidinyl] propanamide, such person shall be sentenced to imprisonment for life.

subsection.header: Controlled Substances Import and Export Act
subsection.text: Section 1010(b) of the Controlled Substances Import and Export Act (21 U.S.C. 960(b)) is amended—

paragraph.text: in paragraph (1), by repealing subparagraph (F); and
by adding at the end the following:

In the case of a violation of subsection (a) involving 400 grams or more of a mixture or substance containing a detectable amount of N-phenyl-N-[1–(2-phenylethyl)–4-piperidinyl] propanamide or 100 grams or more of a mixture or substance containing a detectable amount of any analogue of N-phenyl-N-[1–(2-phenylethyl)–4-piperidinyl] propanamide, such person shall be sentenced to imprisonment for life.
